doc.previous: Christianity emerged in Roman Judea as a Jewish religious sect in the 1st century AD The religion gradually spread out of Jerusalem initially establishing major bases in first Antioch then Alexandria and over time throughout the Empire as well as beyond Imperially authorized persecutions were limited and sporadic with martyrdoms occurring most often under the authority of local officials 551
doc.after: The first persecution by an emperor occurred under Nero and was confined to the city of Rome Tacitus reports that after the Great Fire of Rome in AD 64 some among the population held Nero responsible and that the emperor attempted to deflect blame onto the Christians 552 After Nero a major persecution occurred under the emperor Domitian 553 554 and a persecution in 177 took place at Lugdunum the Gallo Roman religious capital A surviving letter from Pliny the Younger governor of Bythinia to the emperor Trajan describes his persecution and executions of Christians 555 The Decian persecution of 246 251 was a serious threat to the Church but ultimately strengthened Christian defiance 556 Diocletian undertook what was to be the most severe persecution of Christians lasting from 303 to 311
